metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof 3D PRINTING OF FACE SHIELDS DURING COVID-19 PANDEMIC: A TECHNICAL NOTE 3D PRINTING OF FACE SHIELDS DURING COVID-19 PANDEMIC: A TECHNICAL NOTE

body_text.text: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic. 1 COVID-19 concentrates in the upper airway mucosa; 2 procedures involving this location are considered high risk. COVID-19 pandemic created a significant shortage of personal protective equipment (PPE) worldwide.

Professional additive manufacturing providers, makers, and designers in the 3D printing community posted free COVID-19 related 3-dimensional (3D) printer designs on their websites. 1, 3 Most oral and maxillofacial surgeons (OMSs) are familiar with 3D printing technology.
We describe our method of using a 3D printer to print face shields to protect OMSs during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The operator should gather equipment and materials prior to starting process. We used specific 3-D printing materials consisting of a 3-D printer (Prusa ® , MK3s) and polylactic acid (PLA) filaments. We used general crafts materials: velcro ® strip, adhesive foam (Frost king ® ) and transparency film, and general office supplies: a hole puncher and scissors (Table 1) .

There are four phases of creating a face shield: design, digital preparation, printing, and assembly ( Table 2 ). This was previously described in detail elsewhere and details are beyond scope of this report. 4, 5 Briefly, we retrieved the file previously designed by engineer and made publicly available for free download. File was saved in standard tessellation language (STL) from Airwolf 3-D ® (https://airwolf3d.com/2020/03/27/covid-19-face-shield-3d-printable-file/). Next, we digitally prepared (i.e. converted) STL to G-code file using PrusaSlicer ® 2.0. The Gcode is the language used by computer to communicate with the printer. G-code file contains specific information regarding (1) printer setting (i.e. nozzle diameter and position, height limit),

(2) print setting (i.e. 3-D printed layer height, horizontal and vertical dimensions), and (3) filament setting (i.e. type, color, diameter, density). This step is important because it controls the quality of the printed product, and the printer's speed (production time). The G-code file is saved on a secure digital (SD) card. We then transferred the G-code from computer to printer using SD card.

We prepared our printer (Prusa ® MK3s) which is a fused deposited modeling (FDM) printer with additive manufacturing technology and a nozzle (i.e. an extruder). This process consists of polymer (i.e. filament) processing through a heated nozzle with rapid cooling. This step allows deposition of individual layers which create the 3D structure. We placed the filament into the extruder and turned on the printing function. Once the procedure was complete, we had the frame for the shield (Figure 1 ).

Finally, we assembled the shield using crafts materials and office supplies. The velcro ® was cut into 2-10-inch-long strips. Each strip received a 2cm-long slit at each end. Each 10-inch velcro hooked on the lateral projections at each end of frame ( Figure 2 ). This velcro ® secures the frame to the head. Next, the adhesive foam was cut into a 12-inch long strip. We attached the sticky side to the inner circumference of the frame (Figure 2 ). The foam acts as a cushion and prevents abrasions of the user's forehead with extended wear. Using a hole puncher, we punched 3 holes, 4-inches apart on the wide side of the transparency films. Finally, each hole fit snugly into one the 3 rounded projections along the frame (Figure 2 ).

The time needed for production depends on the printer's default speed, size of the nozzle, extruded layer height, and size of object being printed. Maintaining a good balance between printing time and quality is important; adjusting the above parameters should be done with caution in order to maintain the quality of the final 3D object. Increasing extruded layer height or having larger nozzle will decrease the printing time. Our printer's speed was 80-100mm/s. In order to print multiple frames during same time interval (i.e. decrease the production time), we stacked frames on top of each other and then individually separating them ( Figure 3 ). In our project, the required production time was 5 hours. Other designs production time varied from 3.5 to 9.5 hours depending on the size of the original design.

The cost of the face shield depends on the materials and durability of the face shield. Cost ranges from $10 to $177. We recommend printing multiple face shields together (e.g. 200 shields) to reduce the overall cost per shield. Our average cost for printing one face shield was $7.30 (Table 1) .

All parts of the 3D printed face shield should be cleaned and disinfected using Super Sani-Cloth ® Germicidal Disposable Wipes. Cleaning process should take place between procedures and between patients. Once disinfected, the shield can be stored on the frame with the transparency film positioned superiorly so that it does not distort until the next patient encounter.
In case of damage or wear, the parts can easily be removed and replaced.

Despite the knowledge that accumulated over the weeks, the guidelines for diagnosis and treatment are constantly changing. 6 During this Covid-19 pandemic, various PPE is available to be 3D printed (e.g. N 95 masks, 4 googles, etc.) . However, not all provide the same fluid barrier and air filtration protection as FDA-cleared PPE. Nevertheless, we are comfortable using our face shield simply as a physical barrier to respiratory droplets with the caveat that it be used in addition to mandated PPE per institutional guidelines (Figure 3 ).

Using our method, we were able to print 100 face shields which we distributed to various groups: OMS, surgical intensive care unit, otolaryngology (ENT) and anesthesia. We are planning to continue printing face shields to be distributed to Emergency Department and Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery service, among others.
In conclusion, our method of 3D printing face shields is simple and cost-effective. We hope that this report will allow OMS to use available technology to protect themselves and their support staff.

FIGREF0.text: Superior (A) and frontal (B) views of 3D printed frame of face shield. Notice inner circumference (black arrow), lateral projections (red arrows), and rounded projections (yellow arrows).

FIGREF1.text: Inferior (A) and lateral (B) views of assembled face shield. Notice position of velcro ® on the lateral projections (red arrows), foam at inner circumference to improve comfort (black arrow), and transparency film on rounded projections (yellow arrows)

FIGREF2.text: Frontal (A) and lateral (B) views of surgeon with face shield in addition to full PPE.

TABREF1.text: Workflow for face shield (STL: standard tessellation language) Equipment, Materials, and Cost Transparency film (100/pack) Punch 3 holes 4-inches apart on wide side of film

TABREF2.text: Workflow for face shield (STL: standard tessellation language) Design Shield is digitally created Design is saved as STL STL is publicly available Digital preparation Convert STL to G-code file G-code file saved on secure digital card Secure digital card is inserted into printer Printing Polymer is loaded onto printer Printer is activated Assembly Adhesive foam is attached to inner side of frame Velcro is attached to frame 3 holes are punched in transparency film
